"Yes. All men must die, but we are not men."
A blog for women in the asoiaf/got universe.

summary: had she lived // Rhaenys Targaryen-Martell and Daenerys Targaryen “Rhaenys loved spending time with her aunt, and she loved...
caption:
had she lived // Rhaenys Targaryen-Martell and Daenerys Targaryen

“Rhaenys loved spending time with her aunt, and she loved spending time with her niece. Daenerys rarely visited King’s Landing from Dragonstone, but when she did, Rhaenys and her would hang out from sunrise to sunset. It was an excellent way to keep away from family drama, and keep each other’s company.”

title: Daenerys as an anti-Cinderella?
body:
Another asoiaf/fairy tales meta

It’s always fun to wonder which fairy tales goes best with which asoiaf characters (especially the girls, for some reason). For Sansa and Arya, the references are overflowing. With Dany it’s… trickier. Only two – or maybe three – classic tales really fit. Two of those I’ve already talked about in previous posts (Thumbelina and The Fire Bird). There are some general “clues” pointing to Cinderella…

-Viserys, the Anastasia & Drizella duo to Daenerys’s Cinderella

-In ADWD, Cleon the “butcher king” of Astapor make a marriage offer to Daenerys and gift her with a pair of slippers, but

Irri slid the slippers onto Dany’s feet. They were gilded leather, decorated with green freshwater pearls. Does the butcher king believe a pair of pretty slippers will win my hand? “King Cleon is most generous. You may thank him for his lovely gift.” Lovely, but made for a child. Dany had small feet, yet the pointed slippers mashed her toes together.

-Cinderella is named as such for her habit of retreating close to the ashes-filled hearth once her work is done (from “cendres”, the French word for “ashes”). Bettelheim view Cinderella’s behavior as a product of sorrow and grief for her dead mother. For Dany, ash is also linked with sorrow and, first inverted trope, with the mother mourning her dead child:

She could feel the heat inside her, a terrible burning in her womb. Her son was tall and proud, with Drogo’s copper skin and her own silver-gold hair, violet eyes shaped like almonds. And he smiled for her and began to lift his hand toward hers, but when he opened his mouth the fire poured out. She saw his heart burning through his chest, and in an instant he was gone, consumed like a moth by a candle, turned to ash. She wept for her child, the promise of a sweet mouth on her breast, but her tears turned to steam as they touched her skin. – Daenerys, AGOT

There’s also the “Queen of ashes” nickname Dany is sometime dubbed with (more so in the show) and the fact that Cinderella herself is a “queen” of the ashes, somewhat (hence why she’s called “Cinderella”).

-Mirri Maz Duur is an inverted fairy godmother to Dany.

But these are details. Overall, Dany comes off as the anti-Cinderella of asoiaf. This becomes especially apparent in ADWD, where she’s, essentially, a glorified slave to her duties who dreams of escapes with her “prince charming”, i.e. Daario. This all reach a culmination point when she goes to the “ball”, i.e., the grand reopening of the Daznak’s pit. Unlike Cinderella, who’d give anything to attend the ball, Dany would give anything to skip it:

“Even if the pits must open, must Your Grace go yourself?” asked Missandei as she was washing the queen’s hair.

[…]

She would rather have drifted in the fragrant pool all day, eating iced fruit off silver trays and dreaming of a house with a red door, but a queen belongs to her people, not to herself. – Daenerys, ADWD

Whereas the ball meant dreams and freedom for Cinderella, for Dany, it’s the perpetuation of a nightmare. They both present themselves at the event under a veil: a literal one for Dany,

“And over it, the long red veils.” The veils would keep the wind from blowing sand into her mouth. And the red will hide any blood spatters. – Daenerys, ADWD

A metaphorical one for Cinderella, garbed so elegantly that her step mother and half sisters don’t recognize her. This idea of disguise is interesting. For a start, it contrasts with Dany’s refusal to put a veil between herself and Astapor in ASOS. To borrow Clapton’s words on Dany’s white garments in the show, the purpose of the veil is to “remove herself (Dany)” from the situation. Dany’s choice of clothes is a mean of non-attendance, while Cinderella’s costume allows her to go incognito and enjoy the moment. There is the contrasts of colors: Cinderella wears an immaculate, pure white dress (at least in the Disney version), whereas Dany wears yellow silk and a blood-colored veil. Finally, in some versions, the ball attended by Cinderella is a masked ball. This could be significant, since the reopening of the pits prove to be its own kind of masked “ball” (and even more so in the show, where the sons of the Harpy creep inside the pits wearing literal masks):

At the base of the Great Pyramid, Ser Barristan awaited them beside an ornate open palanquin, surrounded by Brazen Beasts. Ser Grandfather, Dany thought. Despite his age, he looked tall and handsome in the armor that she’d given him. “I would be happier if you had Unsullied guards about you today, Your Grace,” the old knight said, as Hizdahr went to greet his cousin. “Half of these Brazen Beasts are untried freedmen.” And the other half are Meereenese of doubtful loyalty, he left unsaid. Selmy mistrusted all the Meereenese, even shavepates.

“And untried they shall remain unless we try them.”

“A mask can hide many things, Your Grace. Is the man behind the owl mask the same owl who guarded you yesterday and the day before?

How can we know?”

“How should Meereen ever come to trust the Brazen Beasts if I do not? There are good brave men beneath those masks. I put my life into their hands.” - Daenerys, ADWD

Behind the drum marched Brazen Beasts four abreast. Some carried cudgels, others staves; all wore pleated skirts, leathern sandals, and patchwork cloaks sewn from squares of many colors to echo the many-colored bricks of Meereen. Their masks gleamed in the sun: boars and bulls, hawks and herons, lions and tigers and bears, fork-tongued serpents and hideous basilisks. – Daenerys, ADWD

In fact, some descriptions of the event, when taken by themselves, almost make it sound like there’s an actual ball happening inside the pit:

Across the pit the Graces sat in flowing robes of many colors, clustered around the austere figure of Galazza Galare, who alone amongst them wore the green. – Daenerys, ADWD

We could even dig further: dancing, in asoiaf, is often used as a euphemism for dying, or is used in scenes going heavy on the death-related subtext. What do people do in a ball? They dance. What do people do in the pits? They die.

“Barsena is very quick,” Reznak said. “She will dance with the boar, Magnificence, and slice him when he passes near her. He will be awash in blood before he falls, you shall see.” – Daenerys, ADWD

Cinderella’s ball is a dream and Dany’s “ball” is a nightmare, but both are woken from it, for the twelfth stroke of midnight will lift the charm. Fun fact, if I’m not mistaken, there were twelve fights planned that day: Khrazz, the Spotted Cat, a “Lysene youth with long blond hair”, an elephant, a bull, a mock battle, a folly with dwarfs, Barsena, a folly with old women and “three more matches”, according to Hzdahr… yup, that makes twelve. Each fight is a “stroke of midnight” for Dany, pulling her from the nightmare, urging her to wake up. At Barsena, she snaps. The charm falls, her carriage turns into a pumpkin and her gown into rags:

She lifted her veil and let it flutter away. She took her tokar off as well. The pearls rattled softly against one another as she unwound the silk.

“Khaleesi? ” Irri asked. “What are you doing?”

“Taking off my floppy ears.” – Daenerys, ADWD

In her haste to flee, she loses a shoe:

“Let me go!” Dany twisted from his grasp. The world seemed to slow as she cleared the parapet. When she landed in the pit she lost a sandal. Running, she could feel the sand between her toes, hot and rough. Ser Barristan was calling after her. – Daenerys, ADWD

The aftermath finds her alone in the grass sea, wearing literal rags (again, not unlike Cinderella), in a dream-like state and wondering what just happened. Unlike Cinderella, Dany has no desire to relive the ball and would much rather stay where she is, with her rags and her animal companion. Both girls experience an unpleasant return to reality. Cinderella must go back to being a slave to her step-mother and half-sister, while Dany knows she must go back to Meereen (which doesn’t quite work out, but).  

Yet for everything nightmarish about it, the reopening of the fighting pits meant something Dany deeply dreamed for and desired: peace. No more bloodshed in the streets of Meereen. The safety of her people. She wanted it and she got it, until the whole farce blew up in her face and the pit of Daznak turned into a pumpkin. I think that’s when she realized it: that the peace was never real, that Hizdahr’s “peace” was an illusion (as many before me have pointed out), a veil that got lifted with the twelve death blows of the pit.

-Cinderella is named as such for her habit of retreating close to the ashes-filled hearth once her work is done (from “cendres”, the French word for “ashes”). Bettelheim view Cinderella’s behavior as a product of sorrow and grief for her dead mother. For Dany, ash is also linked with sorrow and, first inverted trope, with the mother mourning her dead child:

She could feel the heat inside her, a terrible burning in her womb. Her son was tall and proud, with Drogo’s copper skin and her own silver-gold hair, violet eyes shaped like almonds. And he smiled for her and began to lift his hand toward hers, but when he opened his mouth the fire poured out. She saw his heart burning through his chest, and in an instant he was gone, consumed like a moth by a candle, turned to ash. She wept for her child, the promise of a sweet mouth on her breast, but her tears turned to steam as they touched her skin. – Daenerys, AGOT

There’s also the “Queen of ashes” nickname Dany is sometime dubbed with (more so in the show) and the fact that Cinderella herself is a “queen” of the ashes, somewhat (hence why she’s called “Cinderella”).

-Mirri Maz Duur is an inverted fairy godmother to Dany.

But these are details. Overall, Dany comes off as the anti-Cinderella of asoiaf. This becomes especially apparent in ADWD, where she’s, essentially, a glorified slave to her duties who dreams of escapes with her “prince charming”, i.e. Daario. This all reach a culmination point when she goes to the “ball”, i.e., the grand reopening of the Daznak’s pit. Unlike Cinderella, who’d give anything to attend the ball, Dany would give anything to skip it:

“Even if the pits must open, must Your Grace go yourself?” asked Missandei as she was washing the queen’s hair.

[…]

She would rather have drifted in the fragrant pool all day, eating iced fruit off silver trays and dreaming of a house with a red door, but a queen belongs to her people, not to herself. – Daenerys, ADWD

Whereas the ball meant dreams and freedom for Cinderella, for Dany, it’s the perpetuation of a nightmare. They both present themselves at the event under a veil: a literal one for Dany,

“And over it, the long red veils.” The veils would keep the wind from blowing sand into her mouth. And the red will hide any blood spatters. – Daenerys, ADWD

A metaphorical one for Cinderella, garbed so elegantly that her step mother and half sisters don’t recognize her. This idea of disguise is interesting. For a start, it contrasts with Dany’s refusal to put a veil between herself and Astapor in ASOS. To borrow Clapton’s words on Dany’s white garments in the show, the purpose of the veil is to “remove herself (Dany)” from the situation. Dany’s choice of clothes is a mean of non-attendance, while Cinderella’s costume allows her to go incognito and enjoy the moment. There is the contrasts of colors: Cinderella wears an immaculate, pure white dress (at least in the Disney version), whereas Dany wears yellow silk and a blood-colored veil. Finally, in some versions, the ball attended by Cinderella is a masked ball. This could be significant, since the reopening of the pits prove to be its own kind of masked “ball” (and even more so in the show, where the sons of the Harpy creep inside the pits wearing literal masks):

At the base of the Great Pyramid, Ser Barristan awaited them beside an ornate open palanquin, surrounded by Brazen Beasts. Ser Grandfather, Dany thought. Despite his age, he looked tall and handsome in the armor that she’d given him. “I would be happier if you had Unsullied guards about you today, Your Grace,” the old knight said, as Hizdahr went to greet his cousin. “Half of these Brazen Beasts are untried freedmen.” And the other half are Meereenese of doubtful loyalty, he left unsaid. Selmy mistrusted all the Meereenese, even shavepates.

“And untried they shall remain unless we try them.”

“A mask can hide many things, Your Grace. Is the man behind the owl mask the same owl who guarded you yesterday and the day before?

How can we know?”

“How should Meereen ever come to trust the Brazen Beasts if I do not? There are good brave men beneath those masks. I put my life into their hands.” - Daenerys, ADWD

Behind the drum marched Brazen Beasts four abreast. Some carried cudgels, others staves; all wore pleated skirts, leathern sandals, and patchwork cloaks sewn from squares of many colors to echo the many-colored bricks of Meereen. Their masks gleamed in the sun: boars and bulls, hawks and herons, lions and tigers and bears, fork-tongued serpents and hideous basilisks. – Daenerys, ADWD

In fact, some descriptions of the event, when taken by themselves, almost make it sound like there’s an actual ball happening inside the pit:

Across the pit the Graces sat in flowing robes of many colors, clustered around the austere figure of Galazza Galare, who alone amongst them wore the green. – Daenerys, ADWD

We could even dig further: dancing, in asoiaf, is often used as a euphemism for dying, or is used in scenes going heavy on the death-related subtext. What do people do in a ball? They dance. What do people do in the pits? They die.

“Barsena is very quick,” Reznak said. “She will dance with the boar, Magnificence, and slice him when he passes near her. He will be awash in blood before he falls, you shall see.” – Daenerys, ADWD

Cinderella’s ball is a dream and Dany’s “ball” is a nightmare, but both are woken from it, for the twelfth stroke of midnight will lift the charm. Fun fact, if I’m not mistaken, there were twelve fights planned that day: Khrazz, the Spotted Cat, a “Lysene youth with long blond hair”, an elephant, a bull, a mock battle, a folly with dwarfs, Barsena, a folly with old women and “three more matches”, according to Hzdahr… yup, that makes twelve. Each fight is a “stroke of midnight” for Dany, pulling her from the nightmare, urging her to wake up. At Barsena, she snaps. The charm falls, her carriage turns into a pumpkin and her gown into rags:

She lifted her veil and let it flutter away. She took her tokar off as well. The pearls rattled softly against one another as she unwound the silk.

“Khaleesi? ” Irri asked. “What are you doing?”

“Taking off my floppy ears.” – Daenerys, ADWD

In her haste to flee, she loses a shoe:

“Let me go!” Dany twisted from his grasp. The world seemed to slow as she cleared the parapet. When she landed in the pit she lost a sandal. Running, she could feel the sand between her toes, hot and rough. Ser Barristan was calling after her. – Daenerys, ADWD

The aftermath finds her alone in the grass sea, wearing literal rags (again, not unlike Cinderella), in a dream-like state and wondering what just happened. Unlike Cinderella, Dany has no desire to relive the ball and would much rather stay where she is, with her rags and her animal companion. Both girls experience an unpleasant return to reality. Cinderella must go back to being a slave to her step-mother and half-sister, while Dany knows she must go back to Meereen (which doesn’t quite work out, but).  

Yet for everything nightmarish about it, the reopening of the fighting pits meant something Dany deeply dreamed for and desired: peace. No more bloodshed in the streets of Meereen. The safety of her people. She wanted it and she got it, until the whole farce blew up in her face and the pit of Daznak turned into a pumpkin. I think that’s when she realized it: that the peace was never real, that Hizdahr’s “peace” was an illusion (as many before me have pointed out), a veil that got lifted with the twelve death blows of the pit.

summary: Daenerys Targaryen - End Game - Season Eight
title: Daenerys Targaryen - End Game - Season Eight
body:
Full disclosure I still kind of want Dany to be the last boss at the end of Game of Thrones but I have come to accept that this is highly unlikely to happen. This does make me sad because she would make a brilliant villain - what a twist it could have been. Oh well.

Episode 1.

“Why doesn’t your sister like me…burn them all.” I’m kidding. Mostly. But is will find it hard to understand why no one in the north is willing to accept her. I think she genuinely thinks that it was just Jon’s pride holding him back from accepting her and that once she is there the Northerners will come around. They really won’t. If they do then we should congratulate on winning Mary Sue of the year award. But most of the first 2 episodes will be the North rejecting her in various subtle and less subtle ways. This will initially include both Stark sisters though they will warm up to her eventually.

It will be like a bucket of cold water over all her dreams as this will be the first time she will have been amongst the actual people she is trying to conquer without actively setting them on fire and they don’t want her. To make matters worse she will then have to deal with the information that no she wasn’t “born to rule the Seven Kingdoms” as she will discover either at the end of episode 1 or the beginning of episode 2 that she just shagged her nephew and he is ahead of her in the line of succession. Hard times ahead for the Mother of Dragons.

Episode 2.

Things are going to get worse before they get better as not only does she have the fall out of last episode to deal with but this is likely where she meets Arya. Who unlike Sansa is not going to hold back for political reasons. She will likely test her in some way not unlike how she tested Sansa last season. Lets hope Arya doesn’t know at this point that Dany burned Sam’s dad and brother as she is the kind of person who takes real offense when you harm her friends or Jon’s friends. I don’t believe she would threaten her (overtly) or hurt but she might very well be the sister who rejects her the most out of the 2.

This will also likely be where Dany learns she is pregnant if she is going to be preggers this season. This is hopefully going to be a point where we can get some really good character development for her as a character. She could be in one of her lowest points of the season. learn she valuable lessons and finally stop with this irritating divine right of kings crap which pisses me of to no end. Or she just shakes it off and learns nothing of value or merit like all of last seasons hardships. Mary Sue of the year 2 years in a row guys - this girl can’t be stopped. I really hope they use the fact that they have 2 episodes before the first big battle to add all of this interesting character stuff - with 60 minute episodes and only 2 main locations what the hell else are they going to do.

Oh and blah blah they all prepare of the white walkers attacking - I am not saying this every time since so many of the characters overlap there is no point.

Anyway Jon will go to her and his BSOD has ended and confirm he isn’t interested in the throne but he is not really going to understand why this information effects her so much. So much of her sense of worth is based on that belief in her destiny, in that list of extra names she has behind her own name and it is going to be very hard for her (hopefully) to come to terms with this. This is something she will have to do alone and effectively this is where her and Jons relationship ends (for now). The white walkers are attacking - quick someone erect the pillow fort.

Episode 3.

So normally this would be Dany giving aerial support while there is fighting on the ground. However I think she will be grounded during this fight for either 1 of 2 reasons. The first - she goes to fight and someone rats her out - pregnant women are not allowed to lead aerial assaults Dany (give her time) or 2 she begins to fight but due to how distracted she is she is injured and this takes her out of the fight. Hopefully neither of these scenarios lead to Drogons death. I highly doubt it as this is only episode 3 but it can’t be discounted remember everyone can die guys. She will have her moment of character arc culmination from the last episode where she is the one who suggests Jon ride Rhaegal and show him how to do this. This will likely be where she and Sansa come to terms as well. Arya is warming up to her as well but as I mentioned in Arya’s post her little strike force will be out trying to save Winter Town. I do want her to see Arya in a fight though because I feel these 2 will be able to fully appreciate each other when they both recognise the strengths and weaknesses of the other person. Again mirroring the Sansa/Arya bits from last season but we are on a time crunch guys. She will be very upset about not being able to help and so will likely be trying to do what she can from the ground much likely Sansa - again showing these 2 connecting. Eventually the battle concludes and oh no your princess was in another castle guys - the Night King wasn’t there. But there were a lot of lost lives in this battle.

Episode 4.

No Jon you aren’t going to King’s Landing - that is a terrible idea. Aaaaannnndd captured. This is where I expect the full Arya/Dany stuff to kick in - I haven’t mentioned before but there will also likely be a short time skip at this point - if Dany is pregnant this will be shown by a large lump suddenly being attached to the actresses stomach. Anyway he gets caught and Arya is obviously the one sent to save him. If Dany has seen her fight she will be fully on board with this - if not she will be sceptical but willing to do whatever it takes. This is also where Dany will be finally able to accept the truth about Jon and she and Sansa will now be the ones in charge of the army of the living each using their own strengths to lead them. Oh and Bran will hopefully still be there giving info.

Episode 5 and 6.

Big fight - good guys win - yay. Honestly I really can’t figure out much about these 2 episodes as we learn more and the season progresses I think this will become more clear but for now it’s just the same as the other 2 posts. Jon and Dany come to terms and marry. Politically no one will accept it and they have to add Arya into the mix - none of the 3 are happy but are willing to accept it. Dany is the most ok with it as, you know, Targaryen. Everything ends on a reasonably happy note.

Or does it - alternate theory - humour me guys - I just really wanted her to be a villain.

She is never fully able to accept Jon is the heir slowly this knowledge eats away at her sanity and eventually she snaps and  embracing the madness that haunts her family torches the Red Keep and everyone inside. Jon has to fight her dragon to dragon and they both plummet to their deaths. Instead of the Targaryens a new rule is created using the idea from the ancient Roman Triumvirates and 3 people are in charge. Arya, Sansa and Bran/Gendry/Jon (if he survives)/Tyrion/build your own adventure. You never know.

She is never fully able to accept Jon is the heir slowly this knowledge eats away at her sanity and eventually she snaps and  embracing the madness that haunts her family torches the Red Keep and everyone inside. Jon has to fight her dragon to dragon and they both plummet to their deaths. Instead of the Targaryens a new rule is created using the idea from the ancient Roman Triumvirates and 3 people are in charge. Arya, Sansa and Bran/Gendry/Jon (if he survives)/Tyrion/build your own adventure. You never know.
trail.content:
Full disclosure I still kind of want Dany to be the last boss at the end of Game of Thrones but I have come to accept that this is highly unlikely to happen. This does make me sad because she would make a brilliant villain - what a twist it could have been. Oh well.

Episode 1.

“Why doesn’t your sister like me…burn them all.” I’m kidding. Mostly. But is will find it hard to understand why no one in the north is willing to accept her. I think she genuinely thinks that it was just Jon’s pride holding him back from accepting her and that once she is there the Northerners will come around. They really won’t. If they do then we should congratulate on winning Mary Sue of the year award. But most of the first 2 episodes will be the North rejecting her in various subtle and less subtle ways. This will initially include both Stark sisters though they will warm up to her eventually.

It will be like a bucket of cold water over all her dreams as this will be the first time she will have been amongst the actual people she is trying to conquer without actively setting them on fire and they don’t want her. To make matters worse she will then have to deal with the information that no she wasn’t “born to rule the Seven Kingdoms” as she will discover either at the end of episode 1 or the beginning of episode 2 that she just shagged her nephew and he is ahead of her in the line of succession. Hard times ahead for the Mother of Dragons.

Episode 2.

Things are going to get worse before they get better as not only does she have the fall out of last episode to deal with but this is likely where she meets Arya. Who unlike Sansa is not going to hold back for political reasons. She will likely test her in some way not unlike how she tested Sansa last season. Lets hope Arya doesn’t know at this point that Dany burned Sam’s dad and brother as she is the kind of person who takes real offense when you harm her friends or Jon’s friends. I don’t believe she would threaten her (overtly) or hurt but she might very well be the sister who rejects her the most out of the 2.

This will also likely be where Dany learns she is pregnant if she is going to be preggers this season. This is hopefully going to be a point where we can get some really good character development for her as a character. She could be in one of her lowest points of the season. learn she valuable lessons and finally stop with this irritating divine right of kings crap which pisses me of to no end. Or she just shakes it off and learns nothing of value or merit like all of last seasons hardships. Mary Sue of the year 2 years in a row guys - this girl can’t be stopped. I really hope they use the fact that they have 2 episodes before the first big battle to add all of this interesting character stuff - with 60 minute episodes and only 2 main locations what the hell else are they going to do.

Oh and blah blah they all prepare of the white walkers attacking - I am not saying this every time since so many of the characters overlap there is no point.

Anyway Jon will go to her and his BSOD has ended and confirm he isn’t interested in the throne but he is not really going to understand why this information effects her so much. So much of her sense of worth is based on that belief in her destiny, in that list of extra names she has behind her own name and it is going to be very hard for her (hopefully) to come to terms with this. This is something she will have to do alone and effectively this is where her and Jons relationship ends (for now). The white walkers are attacking - quick someone erect the pillow fort.

Episode 3.

So normally this would be Dany giving aerial support while there is fighting on the ground. However I think she will be grounded during this fight for either 1 of 2 reasons. The first - she goes to fight and someone rats her out - pregnant women are not allowed to lead aerial assaults Dany (give her time) or 2 she begins to fight but due to how distracted she is she is injured and this takes her out of the fight. Hopefully neither of these scenarios lead to Drogons death. I highly doubt it as this is only episode 3 but it can’t be discounted remember everyone can die guys. She will have her moment of character arc culmination from the last episode where she is the one who suggests Jon ride Rhaegal and show him how to do this. This will likely be where she and Sansa come to terms as well. Arya is warming up to her as well but as I mentioned in Arya’s post her little strike force will be out trying to save Winter Town. I do want her to see Arya in a fight though because I feel these 2 will be able to fully appreciate each other when they both recognise the strengths and weaknesses of the other person. Again mirroring the Sansa/Arya bits from last season but we are on a time crunch guys. She will be very upset about not being able to help and so will likely be trying to do what she can from the ground much likely Sansa - again showing these 2 connecting. Eventually the battle concludes and oh no your princess was in another castle guys - the Night King wasn’t there. But there were a lot of lost lives in this battle.

Episode 4.

No Jon you aren’t going to King’s Landing - that is a terrible idea. Aaaaannnndd captured. This is where I expect the full Arya/Dany stuff to kick in - I haven’t mentioned before but there will also likely be a short time skip at this point - if Dany is pregnant this will be shown by a large lump suddenly being attached to the actresses stomach. Anyway he gets caught and Arya is obviously the one sent to save him. If Dany has seen her fight she will be fully on board with this - if not she will be sceptical but willing to do whatever it takes. This is also where Dany will be finally able to accept the truth about Jon and she and Sansa will now be the ones in charge of the army of the living each using their own strengths to lead them. Oh and Bran will hopefully still be there giving info.

Episode 5 and 6.

Big fight - good guys win - yay. Honestly I really can’t figure out much about these 2 episodes as we learn more and the season progresses I think this will become more clear but for now it’s just the same as the other 2 posts. Jon and Dany come to terms and marry. Politically no one will accept it and they have to add Arya into the mix - none of the 3 are happy but are willing to accept it. Dany is the most ok with it as, you know, Targaryen. Everything ends on a reasonably happy note.

Or does it - alternate theory - humour me guys - I just really wanted her to be a villain.

She is never fully able to accept Jon is the heir slowly this knowledge eats away at her sanity and eventually she snaps and  embracing the madness that haunts her family torches the Red Keep and everyone inside. Jon has to fight her dragon to dragon and they both plummet to their deaths. Instead of the Targaryens a new rule is created using the idea from the ancient Roman Triumvirates and 3 people are in charge. Arya, Sansa and Bran/Gendry/Jon (if he survives)/Tyrion/build your own adventure. You never know.

body:
Dany is a Khaleesi

So I’ve seen some people posting about how everyone in Westeros views death by fire as like one of the worst ways to go. They would prefer a beheading over it for sure.

I just watched episode 1 of season 2 when one of the bloodrider’s severed Head returns to Dany and one of the Dothraki cries and says that they’ve killed his soul bc they butchered him like an animal and didn’t burn the body.

So I’m not saying burning people alive is okay, but for a long time I’ve thought the Dothraki had a HUGE impact on Dany more than is talked about. She was raised with them practically - the first people she ever led and knew, the first home she had really. Some of her decisions that seem very cruel prob don’t upset the Dothraki in fact they could be praised and seen as shows of strength by the Dothraki, who make up the majority of her forces unless I’m incorrect. 100k?

The dragons, the fire are the reasons why they followed her to begin with, and her riding a dragon parallels a khal riding a horse nicely. Daenerys killing by fire is keeping souls intact to the Dothraki.

She promised the khalasar that they could conquer Westeros and with this comes rape, pillage, etc. Thats their way of life. Does she even have a long term plan for them? For how to give them a better life or are they just pawns in her play for the throne she’s always wanted?

She should be a Khaleesi. She truly doesn’t understand the Westerosi people she now wants to conquer. IMO she can’t be both a good Khaleesi and a good Queen.

summary: Apparently, If Jon is not political, he has Stockholm, I just receaved this kind of messages, how he has Stockholm bc Dany keeps...
question: Apparently, If Jon is not political, he has Stockholm, I just receaved this kind of messages, how he has Stockholm bc Dany keeps him on prisoner, among rapists and pillagers, and dragons. And when he said to Dany, they will see her for what she is, apparently he coming back to his senses after facing death once again, and he actually means that they will see her as a mad queen that she is. He only sleeps with her bc he cannot back off and tried to manipulate her instead. Guess from who s fandom
answer:
1) Jon isn’t prissioner of Dany. She gave a permission to Jon in episode 4 to take his dragonglass and few army and “go to work”. Dany never ever hurt Jon. It’s absolutely idiotical and unserious to compare Stokholm syndrom with Jonerys. Nobody touched Jon, neither raped , neither clashed, neither hurts

2) when Jon said to Dany “They come and see what you are” is parallel phrase from season 1 when tyrion told to Jon “never forget what you are”… Northern people come and see what Dany is. After Dany risked everything for Jon and his friends who really are no one for Dany. Jon found out how big heart she has.


3) Jon bent the knee after Dany accepted to save and protect North. Jon could start Dany’s manipulation before when Dany didn’t accept his story. Didn’t believe in him but noo… he never ever tried to act this way. After Dany is absolutely accepted about Jon, North and Night King. There is no necessary his manipulation. Jon doesn’t need it.

4)if Jon Thinks that Dany is mad. Why didn’t bent the knee with Cersei? Dany was accepted it. Because she realizes they need Cersei’s help. But he didn’t do it. If Jon wasn’t trust Dany absolutely why he sent only one raven to Dany and not in Winterfell too? How he was sure that Dany traveled in North and saved them? Why didn’t sent second raven to Sansa? What could happen if Dany didn’t decide to travel in North? All of them was die. Can you imagine how hard he believed in Dany that he didn’t tried another version?

Thanks

He was absolutely sure who Dany is! He was absolutely sure that Dany saved them!he absolutely 10000000% believe in Dany. She was only one who he mentioned
